channel.title: How to rid of that nasty MD5
channel.description:
[CENTER][COLOR=DimGray]Before anyone asks this is a tutorial explaining on how to get rid of the MD5 hash on passwords.[/COLOR]
[SIZE=1][COLOR=Red]*Note* If you do this after people have already registered on your site, they will have to get a new password because the hash that was taking affect on the server before is now gone, this means that there password you see in hash form is now in text form, so it wont work. Its recommended you do this before people start playing.[/COLOR][/SIZE]
[COLOR=DimGray]1. First thing your going to want to do is find your 'Server Source' Folder. This is the folder that you run and edit the server on.[/COLOR] [COLOR=DimGray] [IMG]http://i305.photobucket.com/albums/nn231/xSynysterFenceX/source.png[/img][/COLOR]
[COLOR=DimGray] 2.Now your going to want to open it up, and open the following document;[/COLOR] [CODE]Client.java[/CODE][COLOR=DimGray]3.Once you do that, your going to want to start at the top, and search this exactly;[/COLOR] [CODE]int loadgame = loadgame(playerName, passHash(playerPass)[/CODE][COLOR=Red]delete passHash so it will end up looking like this;[/COLOR] [CODE]int loadgame = loadgame(playerName, (playerPass)[/CODE][COLOR=DimGray]now again, ctrl + f and search;[/COLOR] [CODE]characterfile.write(passHash(playerPass), 0, passHash(playerPass)[/CODE][COLOR=Red]now delete both passHash from both sides;[/COLOR] [CODE]characterfile.write((playerPass), 0, (playerPass)[/CODE][COLOR=DimGray]now save that file, and compile your server, if you get any errors go over what you deleted and make sure it looks like mine.
now instead of that icky 32424DA7DA7SD8ASD7AS password, you will be able to see the player passwords as they log in.
-v0x [/COLOR][/CENTER]

item.title: How to rid of that nasty MD5
item.dc:creator: @colossusx7 colossusx7
item.description:
@colossusx7 wrote:

Nice, Thanks man…

Read full topic

item.title: How to rid of that nasty MD5
item.dc:creator: @Ghost_in_stack Ghost in stack
item.description:
@Ghost_in_stack wrote:

[quote=“zyle1992, post:70, topic:328328”][quote author=Ghost in stack link=topic=424721.msg3601114#msg3601114 date=1305579351]

Whatever its to complicated for you to understand.

i snickered at that

As did I.

try to learn a bit instead of posting useless comments.

Try to learn a bit about network security instead of claiming we know nothing.

you’re the one who has to learn about network security not me. Saying that SSL/TLS cant encrypt the segments of network connections.
[/quote]

I never said that. I said that SRP wasn’t restricted to only SSL/TLS. And when you said it was only used in those two, I responded with an example, the WoW client.[/quote]

If so, give me another cryptographic protocol that provide communications security

Read full topic

Whatever its to complicated for you to understand.

i snickered at that

As did I.

try to learn a bit instead of posting useless comments.

Try to learn a bit about network security instead of claiming we know nothing.
[/quote]

you’re the one who has to learn about network security not me. Saying that SSL/TLS cant encrypt the segments of network connections.[/quote]

I never said that. I said that SRP wasn’t restricted to only SSL/TLS. And when you said it was only used in those two, I responded with an example, the WoW client.

item.title: How to rid of that nasty MD5
item.dc:creator: @zyle1992 Zymus
item.description:
@zyle1992 wrote:

[quote=“Ghost in stack, post:62, topic:328328”][quote author=zyle1992 link=topic=424721.msg3600753#msg3600753 date=1305529318]

SRP-6 > *

SRP version 6 is used for strong password authentication in SSL/TLS, very secure <3

Or authentication in general. Doesn’t have to be SSL/TLS.

I’m in the process of implementing it into my client.
[/quote]

I think its has to be SSL/TLS due to the fact TLS and SSL encrypt the segments of network connections[/quote]

What? No. Blizzard uses SRP-6a in their WoW client.

item.title: How to rid of that nasty MD5
item.dc:creator: @Ghost_in_stack Ghost in stack
item.description:
@Ghost_in_stack wrote:

deathschaos9:

Hey, you got the right terminology this time; reverse, not decrypt.

I guess their isnt much of a difference between decrypt and reverse. The decryption process is the reverse process of the encryption.

Read full topic

item.source: How to rid of that nasty MD5

item.title: How to rid of that nasty MD5
item.dc:creator: @Ghost_in_stack Ghost in stack
item.description:
@Ghost_in_stack wrote:

[quote=“deathschaos9, post:55, topic:328328”]Now you’ve just contradicted yourself. You said MD5 can’t be decrypted, and you said it can be decrypted. Its impossible to decrypt something that’s not encrypted.

You can find the value of a hash, but you haven’t ‘decrypted’ anything. I realize what you’re trying to say, but you’re using the wrong terminology. ;)[/quote]

So how can u explain online MD5 rainbow tables that are used to reverse MD5 hashes into strings that collide with the original input ?

Read full topic
item.source: How to rid of that nasty MD5

item.title: How to rid of that nasty MD5
item.dc:creator: @deathschaos9 DeathsChaos9
item.description:
@deathschaos9 wrote:

Now you’ve just contradicted yourself. You said MD5 can’t be decrypted, and you said it can be decrypted. Its impossible to decrypt something that’s not encrypted.

You can find the value of a hash, but you haven’t ‘decrypted’ anything. I realize what you’re trying to say, but you’re using the wrong terminology.

Read full topic
item.source: How to rid of that nasty MD5

item.title: How to rid of that nasty MD5
item.dc:creator: @Ghost_in_stack Ghost in stack
item.description:
@Ghost_in_stack wrote:

deathschaos9:

You can’t ‘decrypt’ a hash without a salt either.

Technically MD5 can’t be “decrypted”, it’s a one way hash, their is only one way to ‘decrypt’ a hash, by checking it to a database of hashes and values, get the corresponding hash and return the value, of course this relies on the fact that the hash exists in the database. Yet we can say that an unsalted md5 hash can be decrypted.

Read full topic
item.source: How to rid of that nasty MD5

item.title: How to rid of that nasty MD5
item.dc:creator: @Ghost_in_stack Ghost in stack
item.description:
@Ghost_in_stack wrote:

[quote=“smkscape, post:49, topic:328328”][quote author=m.dog311 link=topic=424721.msg3120899#msg3120899 date=1265512470]
v0x, passwords are meant to be known by 1 person…
[/quote]

This, and MD5 is there to protect that. However its easy to decrypt it.[/quote]

Depends, if the md5 hash is salted (which is always)than its almost impossible to decrypt it.

Read full topic
item.source: How to rid of that nasty MD5

item.title: How to rid of that nasty MD5
item.dc:creator: @Aftermath_961 Aftermath
item.description:
@Aftermath_961 wrote:

There’s pretty much no legitimate reason for anyone hosting / running a server to see users’ passwords. Elementary security is a must, especially if you’re letting someone else host your server. (Most who will use this are just fishing for MITB logins / RS accounts). [And if you’re talking about lost passwords, password reset is a much better way than just retrieving the password].

That said, MD5 is a terrible way to do this, but it’s better than nothing. A decent computer can find a string with the same hash in just a few seconds.

Read full topic
